title: Dasha Zhukova - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: |Education| - Art collector - businesswoman - magazine editor - socialite - (m. 2008; 8 June 1981) is a Russian-American art collector, businesswoman, magazine editor, and socialite. She is the founder of the [Garage Museum of Contemporary Art](/wiki/Garage_Museum_of_Contemporary_Art) and education[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Dasha_Zhukova&action=edit§ion=1)] Darya Alexandrovna Zhukova was born in Moscow on 8 June 1981. [[1]](#cite_note-buro-1) Her father is [Alexander Zhukov](/wiki/Alexander_Zhukov_(businessman)), an oil trader. Her [molecular biology](/wiki/Molecular_biology). Her parents separated when she was 3. [[4]](#cite_note-dashawsj-4) In 1991, she moved with her mother to the United States, settling in the [Houston](/wiki/Houston) area as her mother had relocated due to work. [[1]](#cite_note-buro-1) [[2]](#cite_note-garagemech-2) [[4]](#cite_note-dashawsj-4) They later moved [[4]](#cite_note-dashawsj-4) By the time Yelena retired, she was a professor of molecular biology at [UCLA](/wiki/University_of_California,_Los_Angeles), as well as an authority on diabetes. [[5]](#cite_note-UCLA-5) Zhukova attended a Jewish day-school in California. [[3]](#cite_note-guardian-3) It was a Hebrew college, Dasha's first school in the US, and she attended it for three years. [[5]](#cite_note-UCLA-5) She attended [Pacific Hills School](/wiki/Pacific_Hills_School), graduating in 1999. She graduated with honors from the [University of California, Santa Barbara](/wiki/University_of_California,_Santa_Barbara) with degrees in [Slavic studies](/wiki/Slavic_studies) and [literature](/wiki/Slavic_literature). After becoming involved with Roman Abramovich, she returned to Moscow and later moved to London, where she enrolled at the London's College of Naturopathic Medicine but did not complete the program. [[6]](#cite_note-Silva-6) [[7]](#cite_note-7) Career[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Dasha_Zhukova&action=edit§ion=2)] In 2006, Kova & T.[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] She currently sits on the boards for the [Los Angeles County Museum of Art](/wiki/Los_Angeles_County_Museum_of_Art), Center for Contemporary Culture (part-funded by Abramovich [[11]](#cite_note-11)) in Moscow, a nonprofit organization supporting the advancement of [contemporary art](/wiki/Contemporary_art) and culture in Russia and abroad. In 2012, the center launched the first comprehensive art education program and public archive of [Russian art](/wiki/Russian_art) in the country. In 2014, the institution changed its name to Garage Museum of Contemporary Art and, the following year, moved to its first permanent home in [Gorky Park](/wiki/Gorky_Park_(Moscow)). The building, designed by [Rem Koolhaas](/wiki/Rem_Koolhaas), is a preservation project that transformed a 1968 [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet) [Modernist](/wiki/Modernist) restaurant into a radical space for exhibitions, publishing, research, and education. [[12]](#cite_note-12) [[13]](#cite_note-13) In February 2009, Zhukova was appointed editor-in-chief of the fashion magazine [Pop](/wiki/Pop_(fashion_magazine)). Many in the industry saw her as an unlikely replacement for launch editor [Katie Grand](/wiki/Katie_Grand). [[4]](#cite_note-dashawsj-4) In an interview at the time she was unable to name a single artist she admired, saying she was bad with names. [[3]](#cite_note-guardian-3) She resigned from the position after three issues in November 2010. [[14]](#cite_note-14) In addition, Zhukova is the Editorial Director of [GARAGE](/wiki/GARAGE_Magazine) magazine, [[15]](#cite_note-15) a biannual print publication that focuses on the collaboration between contemporary art and fashion. Since its inception, GARAGE magazine has worked with some of the world's most celebrated creators, and initiated global artistic dialogues. Among the magazine's contributors are artists The magazine took its name and spirit from Garage Museum of Contemporary Art. She also is a founding member of the Culture Shed in New York. Racist chair controversy[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Dasha_Zhukova&action=edit§ion=3)] In 2014, a photograph of Zhukova sitting on a chair designed as a mannequin of a black woman was featured on Buro 24/7, an online fashion publication. The photograph was widely criticized as racist. Buro 24/7 cropped the chair from the photo and Zhukova apologised, describing the chair as artwork and as "commentary on gender and racial politics". Zhukova added, "I utterly abhor racism and would like to apologise to those offended by my participation in this shoot". She to the [Democratic National Committee](/wiki/Democratic_National_Committee). [[21]](#cite_note-21) Personal life[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Dasha_Zhukova&action=edit§ion=5)] In 2008, Zhukova married [Roman Abramovich](/wiki/Roman_Abramovich), a Russian businessman and investor who is the main owner of the private investment company [Millhouse LLC](/wiki/Millhouse_LLC). The couple had two children, a son and daughter, who were both born in the United States. [[22]](#cite_note-MiamiNewsday-22) In August 2017, the couple announced that they would separate. [[23]](#cite_note-23) On 11 October 2019, Zhukova married Stavros Niarchos II, son of [Philip Niarchos](/wiki/Philip_Niarchos), in a civil ceremony in Paris, France. [[24]](#cite_note-ARTnews-24) In March 2021, she gave birth to her third child, and her first with Niarchos, a son named Philip Stavros Niarchos.
